input:
30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)

Covers Software 1.0 (Analysis & Data Pipelines), Software 2.0 (ML), Software 3.0 (Prompt Engineering, RAG, AI Agents, Fine-tuning)
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose and Audience
- Purpose: Educate and promote a free guide; inspire readers to take action on building AI projects.
- Audience: AI learners, aspiring developers, solopreneurs, technical audience eager to build or upskill with hands-on projects.

Step 2: Post Wireframe
- Hook: Short, bold hook focused on the guide and what readers can achieve.
- Body: Present the 3 software paradigms, tease what the guide contains, emphasize accessibility, and encourage action.
- CTA: Ask what project people want to start this weekend.

Step 3: Body Content
You don’t need a PhD—or a big company budget—to build useful AI projects this weekend. I put together a free guide with 30 project ideas. They go from classic analysis (Software 1.0), to machine learning apps (Software 2.0), all the way to prompt engineering, RAG, agents and fine-tuning (Software 3.0). These are real projects you can actually build, whether you’re new to AI or looking to deepen your skill set.

Step 4: CTA
Which project are you excited to start this weekend?

Step 5: Hook
Step 5A: Brainstorming directions:
- [User phrasing]: 30 AI Projects You Can Build This Weekend (Free Guide)
- [Problem/solution]: Too many AI tutorials, not enough projects. Here are 30 ideas you can actually build.
- [Trend/urgency]: AI is moving fast. Build something real this weekend with these project ideas.
- [Beginner-to-expert]: From data pipelines to LLMs—30 projects for all levels.
- [Results]: I curated 30 project ideas (with resources) so you can skip the overwhelm and start building.

Step 5B: Notes:
- [User phrasing] captures the value and immediacy
- [Problem/solution] highlights how ideas are actionable
- [Trend] taps into the urgency of AI
- [Beginner] focuses on range
- [Results] emphasizes curation

Step 5C: Choose the direction: Use the user’s phrasing as it is strong and direct, and reflects Shaw’s voice. Tweak slightly for clarity.

Step 6: Combine into Draft

30 AI projects you can build this weekend (free guide)

You don’t need a PhD—or a company budget—to build useful AI projects right now.

I’ve put together a free guide with 30 project ideas:
- Software 1.0: Analysis & data pipelines
- Software 2.0: Machine learning apps
- Software 3.0: Prompt engineering, RAG, agents, and fine-tuning

These are projects you can actually build—whether you’re just starting out or want to deepen your skills.
(Link to guide)

Which project are you excited to start this weekend?

Step 7: Style, Voice, and Flow Review
- Factual, not hyped
- One em dash present (justified)
- Bullet points for scan ability
- Ends with single CTA
- Tone aligns with Shaw’s friendly, clear, and actionable voice

Step 8: Final Post
